cells.data:
$$y'' + p(t)y' + q(t)y = g(t)$$
The linear coefficient ODE is a special case:
$$y'' + ay' + by = g(t)$$
The differential operator $L[y]$ is in this case $y'' + ay' + by$, but technically we have
$$L[y] = \left( \frac{d^2}{dx^2} + a\frac{d}{dx} + b \right) y$$

Then we can have equations like $L[y] = 0, L[y] = g$.
If we have $L[y_1] = 0, L[y_2] = g$, then clearly $L[y_1 + y_2] = L[y_1] + L[y_2] = g$. Similarly, $L[cy_1 + y_2] = L[cy_1] + L[y_2] = g$.

We can expand this to arbitrary $y_n, g_m$ such that $L[y] = g_1 + g_2 + \dots + g_m, L[y_1 + y_2 + \dots + y_n] = L[y]$ because some number of $y_i : 0 \lt i \lt n$ exist such that $L[y_i] = 0$, and $m$ $y_i$ exist such that $L[y_i] = g_i$.

Cf. Worksheet #$12$
